texts.shortText: Large fan-like species, often mistaken for a sea-fan (Gorgonacea). The erect colony has an internal chitinous skeleton and is fairly regularly branched in a single plane, to form a fan-like structure up to 400 mm tall. Main stem thick and flattened, but smaller branches rounded in cross-section and grey or yellow-brown in colour. The small polyps are housed within bracket-shaped projections (hydrophores) extending from the sides of the stems, are elongate and bear scattered tentacles irregularly over the body. When preserved they are knob-like, but in life presumably elongate. Reproductive individuals are small and spherical.
Colony up to 400 mm tall and with a span of 300 mm.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: West coast of Cape Peninsula to KwaZulu-Natal.

Unusual appearance for a hydroid and looks much more like a sea-fan. Found on rocky reefs from about 12-130 m depth and extends from the rock face out into the water to intercept the dominant current.
Presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water.
Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies, but male and females individuals look similar. Free-living stages have not been observed.

Fairly unique among regional hydroids due to the stiff, branching, fan-like structure and this is the only such species in the Western Cape (one other species in the genus known form Mozambique). Often mistaken for a sea-fan (Gorgonacean), but the polyps are quite different â€“ those of seafans having a ring of 8 elongate tentacles rather than elongate form with scattered tentacles found in Solandaria species.

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 56).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 59).
